title.children: A perfect storm is brewing at Lillian's cafe: Rising costs and fewer customers coming through the door

title.children: They're the Pacific's 'mini Olympics'. But with a stadium gifted by China and millions invested, not everyone wants them

title.children: Joint naval drills between US, Australia, India and Japan 'more important than ever'

image.altText: Grace Corvo looks at the camera.

title.children: 'Young people are hustlers': Gen Z 'willing to do what they need to' to make ends meet

image.altText: Journalist Cheng Lei is seen smiling while seated with the Shanghai waterfront in the background.

title.children: Ten hours of sunlight per year: Australian Cheng Lei's first message from Chinese prison

image.altText: Lowe gestures with one hand, sitting at a table in suit and tie, a news camera visible behind him.

items.synopsis: Philip Lowe will face the house economics committee hearing as RBA governor for the final time this morning. Meanwhile US inflation continues to cool, increasing the chance the Federal Reserve will leave rates on hold at its next meeting. Follow live.

title.children: Outgoing RBA boss Philip Lowe to face final parliamentary grilling, US inflation cools

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's a very quick whip-around of some other results that have come out this morning: Furniture retailer Nick Scali has posted a record net profit of $101.1 million, attributing growth to a fall in shipping delays after the pandemic, resulting in more sales. Baby Bunting's profit took a hit, falling to $14.5 million — down 51% from the previous financial year. Acting CEO Darin Hoekman said the fall was due to parents pulling back on spending due to cost-of-living pressures. Newcrest Mining reported a $US778 million profit in FY23.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Nick Scali posts record profit, Baby Bunting earnings slide

children.content: Here's a very quick whip-around of some other results that have come out this morning:
Furniture retailer
Nick Scali
has posted a record net profit of $101.1 million, attributing growth to a fall in shipping delays after the pandemic, resulting in more sales.
Baby Bunting's

profit took a hit, falling to $14.5 million — down 51% from the previous financial year. Acting CEO Darin Hoekman said the fall was due to parents pulling back on spending due to cost-of-living pressures.
Newcrest Mining
reported a $US778 million profit in FY23.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: REA Group, the company behind property advertising site realestate.com.au, has posted its earnings for the most recent financial year, recording a net profit of $372 million — down 9% on the last financial year's figure. The Group told the ASX it delivered a "resilient result in challenging market conditions", which included "significantly lower" listings compared to FY22. CEO Owen Wilson said the company's revenue growth was driven by its REA India division, but flagged there might be higher losses in the future. "The fundamentals of the Australian property market remain healthy," he said. "We are continuing to see strong demand and a return to price growth, and this is converting to a more attractive market for sellers. "We believe the stabilisation of interest rates is within sight and we expect this will lead to an increase in market activity. "[REA Group] are focused on delivering products that provide the greatest value to customers and enhance the experience of our audience, and we see significant opportunities in the year ahead." REA Group will cut its full-year dividends by 4% to $1.58.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: REA Group reports $372 million profit after 'challenging market conditions'

children.content: REA Group, the company behind property advertising site realestate.com.au, has posted its earnings for the most recent financial year,
recording a net profit of $372 million
— down 9% on the last financial year's figure.
The Group told the ASX it delivered a
"resilient result in challenging market conditions"
, which included "significantly lower" listings compared to FY22.
CEO Owen Wilson said the company's revenue growth was driven by its REA India division, but
flagged there might be higher losses in the future
"The fundamentals of the Australian property market remain healthy," he said.
"We are continuing to see strong demand and a return to price growth, and this is
converting to a more attractive market for sellers
"We believe the
stabilisation of interest rates is within sight
and we expect this will
lead to an increase in market activity
"[REA Group] are focused on delivering products that provide the greatest value to customers and enhance the experience of our audience, and we see significant opportunities in the year ahead."
REA Group will cut its full-year dividends by 4% to $1.58.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The financial regulator has launched civil proceedings against Active Super over claims it misled customers by claiming it was an "ethical and responsible superannuation fund". On its website, Active Super claimed not to invest in industries that threatened the environment and the community — meaning it didn't invest funds in tobacco manufacturing, gambling, coal mining and oil tar sands. The super fund also said it added Russia to its list of excluded countries after it illegally invaded Ukraine last year. But ASIC alleges Active Super "exposed its members to investments it claimed to restrict or eliminate", claiming it had 28 holdings, directly or indirectly, that contradicted its ethical stance, between February 1, 2021 and June 30, 2023. Those holdings included: Gambling : Skycity Entertainment Group Limited, PointsBet Holdings Limited, The Star Entertainment Group Limited, The Lottery Corporation Limited and Tabcorp Holdings Limited; Tobacco : Amcor PLC; Russian entities : Gazprom PJSC and Rosneft Oil Company; Oil Tar Sands : ConocoPhillips; Coal Mining : Coronado Global Resources Inc., New Hope Corporation Limited and Whitehaven Coal Limited. ASIC also alleges Active Super claimed it would stop investing in Russian companies from May 2022, but holdings in Russian securities remained in place as of the end of June 2023. "There is much competition among super funds for new members, and we know that funds seek to attract members with promises their investments will not be exposed to certain industries," said Sarah Court, ASIC's Deputy Chair. "When making these claims super funds must have evidence to back their claims and ensure they are not promising exclusions that they cannot guarantee." It's the third greenwashing civil penalty ASIC has launched, after taking action against Mercer Super and Vanguard. A spokesperson for Active Super said the fund has cooperated with ASIC's investigation, and " welcomes increased scrutiny on ESG disclosure standards as being good for members, the super industry and the community". "As the matter is before the courts we are unable to comment further," the spokesperson said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASIC takes Active Super to court for falsely claiming it was an 'ethical' superannuation fund

ASIC also alleges Active Super claimed it would stop investing in Russian companies from May 2022, but holdings in Russian securities remained in place as of the end of June 2023.

"There is much competition among super funds for new members, and we know that funds seek to attract members with promises their investments will not be exposed to certain industries," said Sarah Court, ASIC's Deputy Chair.
"When making these claims super funds must have evidence to back their claims and ensure they are not promising exclusions that they cannot guarantee."
It's the
third greenwashing civil penalty ASIC has launched

and

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Former US President Donald Trump says a trial on charges of him trying to overturn his 2020 election loss to Joe Biden should happen only after the 2024 US elections. "Such a trial ...... should only happen, if at all, AFTER THE ELECTION," Trump wrote in a post on his Truth Social platform. That date would have the trial get underway just two weeks before the first votes are cast in the 2024 Republican presidential primary, a race in which Trump is the frontrunner. US Special Counsel Jack Smith's office asked a judge in a court filing on Thursday to start the trial on January 2 in part due to the public's interest in a speedy trial. Smith's office said interest was "of particular significance here, where the defendant, a former president, is charged with conspiring to overturn the legitimate results of the 2020 presidential election, obstruct the certification of the election results, and discount citizens’ legitimate votes." A spokesperson for Trump says Smith and the Justice Department "are blatantly playing political games", citing Trump's status as a frontrunner in the 2024 election. Prosecutors predict it will take about four to six weeks to put forward the bulk of their case against Trump at trial. Trump last week pleaded not guilty to charges over the alleged election conspiracy.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Trump says trial on election case should be after 2024 election

props.alt: A man in a blue suit, erd tie, orange face speaking on a podium that reads trump 2024

children.content: (Reuters)
Former US President Donald Trump says a trial on charges of him trying to overturn his 2020 election loss to Joe Biden should happen only after the 2024 US elections.
"Such a trial ...... should only happen, if at all, AFTER THE ELECTION," Trump wrote in a post on his Truth Social platform.
That date would have the trial get underway just two weeks before the first votes are cast in the 2024 Republican presidential primary, a race in which Trump is the frontrunner.
US Special Counsel Jack Smith's office asked a judge in a court filing on Thursday to start the trial on January 2 in part due to the public's interest in a speedy trial.

Smith's office said interest was "of particular significance here, where the defendant, a former president, is charged with conspiring to overturn the legitimate results of the 2020 presidential election, obstruct the certification of the election results, and discount citizens’ legitimate votes."
A spokesperson for Trump says Smith and the Justice Department "are blatantly playing political games", citing Trump's status as a frontrunner in the 2024 election.
Prosecutors predict it will take about four to six weeks to put forward the bulk of their case against Trump at trial.
Trump last week pleaded not guilty to charges over the alleged election conspiracy.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Thousands of people are sheltering in cars, churches and the local airport on the fire-devastated Hawaiian island of Maui, where 36 people have been killed and several hundred buildings razed. US President Joe Biden has declared a "major disaster", promising to send more help and supplies to the island, where some essentials are starting to run short. Hawaii Governor Josh Green says Hawaii had not had such a fatal event since about the time it won statehood, when a tsunami killed 61 people more than 60 years ago. He expects the death toll will rise. You can keep reading the latest updates here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hawaii wildfires could be island's most fatal event in years

featuredLink.title: Biden declares 'major disaster' on Hawaiian island after 36 die in fire disaster

children.content: Thousands of people are sheltering in cars, churches and the local airport on the fire-devastated Hawaiian island of Maui, where
36 people have been killed
and several hundred buildings razed.
US President Joe Biden has declared a "major disaster", promising
to send more help and supplies
to the island, where some essentials
are starting to run short.
Hawaii Governor Josh Green says Hawaii had not had such a fatal event since about the time it won statehood, when a tsunami killed 61 people more than 60 years ago.
He expects the death toll will rise.
You can keep reading the latest updates here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Former Socceroo and commentator Craig Foster has told ABC News Breakfast the Matildas' success in their World Cup campaign is an opportunity to talk about better pay. He says he supports comments made by a former Matilda Mel Barbieri telling Prime Minister Anthony Albanese to stop talking about a public holiday if the Matildas win the tournament and begin more conversations about equal pay. "She's a legend and came out and said 'I'm frustrated with this, Albo, stop talking about a public holiday, or just a public holiday, because most of us would love one,'" he says. "We need more funding, we're on $25,000 a year for over 30 weeks of a season in the A-League women's and need more and help. "Let's start that conversation."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Ex-Socceroo Craig Foster calls for equal pay for women's soccer ahead of tomorrow's game

props.alt: A man with white hair and beard, denim jacket and matildas scarf

children.content: (ABC News Breakfast )
Former Socceroo and commentator Craig Foster has told ABC News Breakfast the Matildas' success in their World Cup campaign is an opportunity to talk about better pay.

He says he supports comments made by a former Matilda Mel Barbieri telling Prime Minister Anthony Albanese to stop talking about a public holiday if the Matildas win the tournament and begin more conversations about equal pay.
"She's a legend and came out and said 'I'm frustrated with this, Albo, stop talking about a public holiday, or just a public holiday, because most of us would love one,'" he says.
"We need more funding, we're on $25,000 a year for over 30 weeks of a season in the A-League women's and need more and help.
"Let's start that conversation."
